\title[Thermodynamic formalism and linear response]{Thermodynamic formalism
  and linear response theory for non-equilibrium steady states}

\author{Thomas Speck}
\address{Institut f\"ur Physik, Johannes Gutenberg-Universit\"at Mainz,
  Staudingerweg 7-9, 55128 Mainz, Germany}

\begin{abstract}
  The accurate determination of transport coefficients in numerical
  simulations is becoming increasingly important in a wide range of
  applications. Here we consider the linear response in systems driven away
  from thermal equilibrium into a non-equilibrium steady state with
  non-vanishing entropy production rate. A simple derivation of a general
  response formula is presented. For Markov processes we explicitly construct
  the conjugate quantities and discuss their relation with known response
  formulas. Emphasis is put on the formal analogy with thermodynamic
  potentials and some consequences are discussed.
\end{abstract}



\section{Introduction}

One of the objectives of computational sciences is the accurate prediction of
material properties. The determination of transport coefficients (\emph{e.g.},
conductivities and mobilities) remains a challenge since, in general, it
implies currents and thus non-equilibrium conditions. Illustrative as well as
technologically important examples include the efficient transport of charges
in organic semiconductors~\cite{coro07,poel14} and across thin membranes in
reverse osmosis~\cite{kalr03}. While many sophisticated numerical methods have
been developed based on thermal equilibrium, for driven systems one typically
has to resort to brute-force computer experiments.

Sufficiently close to equilibrium transport coefficients can be determined
from equilibrium fluctuations via the fluctuation-dissipation
theorem~\cite{kubo}. There have been considerable efforts to find general
principles also for the linear response of non-equilibrium states (for
examples see Refs.~\cite{spec06,baie09,chet09,pros09,spec10,warr12}, for more
complete reviews we refer to Refs.~\cite{marc08,seif12,baie13} and references
therein). There is now a zoo of different approaches and derivations yielding
(sometimes unrecognized) equivalent results. One reason might be that actually
several conjugate observables (and their linear combinations) are equivalent
in determining the response~\cite{seif10}.

Extending the notion of statistical ensembles to trajectories (time-ordered
sequences of dynamic events) is currently receiving considerable
attention~\cite{leco07a,garr09,turn14}. Pivotal here is the concept of
``canonical'' path ensembles (also appearing under the names
$s$-ensemble~\cite{mero05,garr10}, tilted ensemble, or Esscher transform) in
which trajectories are biased by a time-integrated observable. Under certain
conditions typical trajectories in the canonical path ensemble are equivalent
to trajectories in the original processes with fixed value of the
observable~\cite{chet13,chet14,szav15}. The purpose of this letter is to
follow these ideas and apply them to the linear response around a
non-equilibrium steady state. We derive a general response formula and show
that it contains previously derived results, in particular the response
formula by Warren and Allen~\cite{warr12} and the path weight
representation~\cite{baie09,seif10,baie13}.

\section{Background: Canonical structure}

The mathematical structure of equilibrium statistical mechanics is based on
pairs of an extensive quantity (volume, particle number) and the conjugate
intensive quantity (pressure, chemical potential), which are related through
thermodynamic potentials (free energies). What makes the formalism so powerful
is that these potentials are also generating functions encoding the full
statistics of the non-conserved extensive quantities. As a corollary,
fluctuations encode the response of thermodynamic observables to a small
external perturbation.

Pairs of conjugate quantities also arise for non-equilibrium steady states
(NESS), where non-zero intensive affinities $f^i$ (the generalized forces)
give rise to transport and thus extensive (generalized) distances $X^i_\tau$
with average entropy production $\sum_if^i{\langle {X^i_\tau} \rangle}$. To illustrate the
situation for driven systems, consider the distribution $P_0(X,\tau)$ of one
such generalized distance $X_\tau\sim\tau$ measured in thermal equilibrium
(\emph{i.e.}, $f=0$) over time $\tau$ (which here plays a role similar to
system size in conventional statistical mechanics). We define the generating
function

the old quest for a non-equilibrium ``potential'', the analog of thermodynamic
potentials determining state functions and justifying variation
principles~\cite{mart06}. Indeed, Onsager's seminal insight has been that
\emph{in the linear response regime} ``the rate of increase of the entropy
plays the role of a potential''~\cite{onsa31}, namely

($\asymp$ denotes the asymptotic limit of $\tau$ becoming larger than the
longest correlation time). That $\ln Z_0\asymp\tau{\varphi}(f)$ (Eq.~(\ref{eq:Z})

larger affinities can already be seen by realizing that any generating
function is convex (and so is the equilibrium free energy). In a NESS,
however, such a property would preclude established phenomena like a negative
differential mobility~\cite{jack08}. In the mentioned canonical path
ensembles, generating functions $Z_f(s;\tau)$ (we now use $s$ as the argument
and $f$ to fix the steady state) play the role of partition functions. As
sketched in Fig.~\ref{fig:sketch}, however, changing $s$ still does not trace
a change of the affinities alone but involves a rather complicated, non-local
transformation also of the
interactions~\cite{jack10a,spec11,chet13,chet14}. In the following, we
demonstrate that for small $s$ this transformation is considerably simpler and
reduces to previously obtained results for the linear response in NESS.
